job_title: Front Office Manager in Bucharest, Bucuresti
pros:
Very good opportunities. All promotions are done internally - no waiting list or minimum time before trying for a higher position. It all depends on your performance and what you can do to rise above the others.

Takes good care of their employees. Once you're in, you can expect to stay with the company for a long time. Haven't heard of unexpected cuts, employees are transferred to other projects rather than fired. If you feel that your current position isn't a good fit for you, they'll help you find one that is. 

Yearly salary increases, depending on performance, with a yearly bonus (that can go as high as a three-month pay all at once)
cons:
Most likely will not be able to join on a non-starter position. 

Expect to go beyond what is asked of you in order to advance - it will not go unappreciated though

pros: It was an opportunity to get to know how Chinese companies operate. Even a bad experience is a learning opportunity. Huawei has great products, but the way they operate their company in EU makes they can't fix a breakthrough in the market. Out of 100 customers, maybe 1 or 2 want to collaborate with Huawei. Salaries are a bit higher than what other companies are offering, but is it worth to offer your credibility for some extra bucks?
cons:
- Chinese management all over the place. These guys, don't know the market, they don't even know about professional sales management. The only thing they repeat like a parrot: "Where's the PO?" 
- Management doesn't want you to talk in your local language because they don't understand what you're saying. But they speak Chinese all the time.
- Chinese management is rude. They're even more rude to Chinese employees.
- Chinese management is incompetent according to local standards and isn't adding any value. They're just there to control and to put pressure. 
- The only thing Chinese management is looking after is to maintain a positive perception towards their upper management and HQ. If they don't they get punished and sent back to China.
- They're not taking advantage of your experience, they just want to make use of your professional network. Instead of learning from you, they stick to their way of working and want to turn you into a Chinese robot that obeys blindly. There is no room for constructive feedback.
- Once they sucked all knowledge and energy out of you, they just dump you. 
- They're not interested in any form of people management.

job_title: Machine Learning Researcher in Burnaby, BC
pros: I have nothing positive to say.
cons:
1. If you are not Chinese, you will feel excluded. The majority of employees are Chinese, formal communication is in Chinese. I felt like a second class employee during my tenure.
2. My manager did not know how to use a software versioning system. Development with them was a nightmare. Code was being shared through zip files.
3. Most people in management know very little about the mathematics of machine learning. If you communicate what they are saying does not make sense, they will tell you to implement it anyway. When it doesn't work you will get the blame because you did not "debug" it properly.
4. Management tracks your hours not your productivity.
5. Management will shame you in front of other employees instead of giving you feedback in private. There have been instances where my manager rolled their eyes as I was explaining what I was doing. There were times when I was told that management was talking behind my back.
6. You will not receive a GPU enabled device for the first three months of your tenure. There is a very limited GPU server and you will not be able to run your job there.
7. If you talk to the director or human resources, they are not there mediate.
8. As a researcher you have no opportunity to do a literature review and come up with proposal. There is a proposal process, but at the end of the day you end up doing what your manager wants you to do.
9. The research group as a whole is disoriented. It is not known if the goal is to publish or a product.
10. You will have less access to data because of US sanctions. You are better off working in any other company when it comes to data.

review_title: Highly competitive company with result driven culture
pros:
Huawei gives you as many chances you are willing to take and throws you challenges you are capable of.
In my career of working with 5 MNCs, this company gives you real 360 Deg feedback option to rate your appraiser. 
Its a common scenario where an engineer with perseverence and good ideas grow to become a program manager or business head in a span of 3 to 4 years. The result being some employees becoming managers of people who were their managers at the beginning. It happens regularly here, where results of indivual is appreciated and rewarded at top of the market compensation. 
Also i have never seen an employee getting fired on basis of performance without giving him/her considerable amount of changes in different areas to prove themselves. Even then, those cases will be audited and reviewed if its an objective decision by the ethics comittee.
Most of all , they respect experienced members no matter the age and dont judget them on basis of 1 or 2 poor year(s). People with experience adapability to environments similar to start-ups and skills to match the role they are in , grow faster here. Politics is least found here, and mostly conducted by very few personalities as its widely condemed here.
cons:
1. Business strategies planned at Head quarters. But over the years its being fedarated.
2. You have be on your toes all the time here grow consitently as its result driven and your last year achievements dont matter. What you are doing now will only matter. So some people will struggle with that notion.
3. Some times communcation gap delays progress of work execution as the company operates in bi-lingual mode with english and chinese used extensively across the board. Lately the IT systems improved drastically to overcome the language gap.

job_title: Senior Marketing Manager in London, England
pros: Huawei is a highly successful company that has come to dominate the telecoms infrastructure industry in a few short years.  It offers high quality, innovative products and invests heavily in R&D.  Huwei has simply out competed Ericsson and Nokia by first undercutting them and then out engineering them.  The company invests hugely in engineering, but is no particularly creative or innovative.
cons:
Huawei is not a good work environment for the Western workforce.  It is a Chinese company with some international presence.  Westerners are tolerated at best.  No Westerner can have any real authority or influence.  Westerners aren't really trusted and the cultural expectations of a Western workforce are barely acknowledged by Chinese Management.  The organization is hugely hierarchical and fast-track managers are often catapulted into roles that they have no understanding of and no real ability in.  Decision making is highly centralised, as are budgets.  Forward planning and reasonable treatment of employees is rare.  The companies Personal Business Objectives drive a lack of cooperation and "big picture" thinking.  People focus purely on their personal business objectives and the financial rewards they bring (and the rewards can be huge) without any real analysis of whether they are the "right" things to do.
This all contributes to a highly unpleasant atmosphere.  Knee-jerk reactions, last-minute decision making,  lack of consultation and micro-management.  
Huawei pays well, but you sell your soul, and no (Western) employees really enjoy the company.
